clusters.title: Allotments are hard work and fickle, but joyous too | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Allotments are hard work and fickle, but joyous too | Letters: Lalage Snow, Laurie Nettle and Stephen Pound respond to an article on the struggles of keeping an allotment

items.title: Allotments are hard work and fickle, but joyous too | Letters
items.standfirst: Lalage Snow, Laurie Nettle and Stephen Pound respond to an article on the struggles of keeping an allotmentAllotments were originally “allotted” to the landless poor of the 18th century to give them dignity, a means of eating and reprieve from the daily grind of land or industrial work (The one change that worked: I gave up my allotment – and accepted who I really am, 18 August). They were a necessity during the two world wars, after which Britain had never been leaner, fitter or taller.Today, we are not as hungry as our ancestors were and life is convenient. However, we are in the throes of obesity, diabetes and mental health crises, we stand on the edge of food supply catastrophe (for example, the tomato crisis of early 2023) and climate change is heavily affecting farmers. I had three children under three and I took on an allotment in my village when war in Ukraine broke out because I wanted to learn, and I wanted to be less reliant on a fragile food system that supplies tasteless fruit and vegetables. I knew little about growing, but quickly came to see that vegetable growing is hard work. Continue reading...
items.content: Lalage Snow, Laurie Nettle and Stephen Pound respond to an article on the struggles of keeping an allotmentAllotments were originally “allotted” to the landless poor of the 18th century to give them dignity, a means of eating and reprieve from the daily grind of land or industrial work (The one change that worked: I gave up my allotment – and accepted who I really am, 18 August). They were a necessity during the two world wars, after which Britain had never been leaner, fitter or taller.Today, we are not as hungry as our ancestors were and life is convenient. However, we are in the throes of obesity, diabetes and mental health crises, we stand on the edge of food supply catastrophe (for example, the tomato crisis of early 2023) and climate change is heavily affecting farmers. I had three children under three and I took on an allotment in my village when war in Ukraine broke out because I wanted to learn, and I wanted to be less reliant on a fragile food system that supplies tasteless fruit and vegetables. I knew little about growing, but quickly came to see that vegetable growing is hard work. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the challenges and joys of maintaining allotments.
Allotments were originally for the landless poor to provide food and dignity.
The article mentions the importance of allotments during wartime.
It highlights the current issues of obesity, food supply, and climate change.
The author shares their personal experience of starting an allotment.

clusters.title: Let’s not pretend body-shaming ever went away | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Let’s not pretend body-shaming ever went away | Letter: I can’t remember a time when my weight was not connected to my worth, says Lindsay Kirker

items.title: Let’s not pretend body-shaming ever went away | Letter
items.standfirst: I can’t remember a time when my weight was not connected to my worth, says Lindsay KirkerThank you for Arwa Mahdawi’s article (Would an ‘Unsexiest Women Alive’ list be published today? Maybe not – but body-shaming is definitely back, 19 August). I keep hearing about the 1990s being a toxic period for women. But when exactly did that stop? When was this idyllic period in which body acceptance took place? Because I must have missed it. I would have welcomed a break from obsessing about my body, calorie counting, and from the feeling of being a total failure whenever I stopped running.I was born in 1984, developed early, and was taught that the additional space I took up with my body was shameful. I remember the teacher calling me up to retrieve my test results as the classroom began a steady chant of “Mooooooo”. Continue reading...
items.content: I can’t remember a time when my weight was not connected to my worth, says Lindsay KirkerThank you for Arwa Mahdawi’s article (Would an ‘Unsexiest Women Alive’ list be published today? When was this idyllic period in which body acceptance took place? Because I must have missed it. I would have welcomed a break from obsessing about my body, calorie counting, and from the feeling of being a total failure whenever I stopped running.I was born in 1984, developed early, and was taught that the additional space I took up with my body was shameful. I remember the teacher calling me up to retrieve my test results as the classroom began a steady chant of “Mooooooo”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The letter responds to an article about body-shaming.
The author questions when body acceptance truly began.
She describes her experiences with body image issues since childhood.
The author recalls being shamed for her body size in school.
The letter reflects on the ongoing struggle with body image.

clusters.title: Maha is backing this ‘natural’ infertility treatment. Is it the right’s path to limiting IVF?
clusters.neutral_headline: Maha is backing this ‘natural’ infertility treatment. Is it the right’s path to limiting IVF?: Conservatives are promoting ‘restorative reproductive medicine’ instead of Trump’s promise to support IVF. Doctors are worried

items.title: Maha is backing this ‘natural’ infertility treatment. Is it the right’s path to limiting IVF?
items.standfirst: Conservatives are promoting ‘restorative reproductive medicine’ instead of Trump’s promise to support IVF. Doctors are worriedFor Erica L and her husband, in-vitro fertilization was the “nuclear option”.After two years of trying to conceive, Erica and her husband had no idea why they could not have a baby. Doctors said only that they had “unexplained infertility”, a non-diagnosis of a diagnosis that is given to an estimated 15% of people trying to conceive. Erica was not ideologically opposed to trying IVF, but felt daunted by the price and unpredictability. Continue reading...
items.content: Conservatives are promoting ‘restorative reproductive medicine’ instead of Trump’s promise to support IVF. Doctors are worriedFor Erica L and her husband, in-vitro fertilization was the “nuclear option”.After two years of trying to conceive, Erica and her husband had no idea why they could not have a baby. Doctors said only that they had “unexplained infertility”, a non-diagnosis of a diagnosis that is given to an estimated 15% of people trying to conceive. Erica was not ideologically opposed to trying IVF, but felt daunted by the price and unpredictability. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Conservatives are promoting "restorative reproductive medicine."
This is instead of Trump's promise to support IVF.
Doctors are expressing concerns about this approach.
The article discusses the experiences of couples with infertility.
It explores the financial and emotional challenges of IVF.

clusters.title: Alarming levels of Pfas in blood of those living near US air force base, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Alarming levels of Pfas in blood of those living near US air force base, study finds: Toxic ‘forever chemicals’ were found at a level 10 times higher than people who did not work in contaminated zone

items.title: Alarming levels of Pfas in blood of those living near US air force base, study finds
items.standfirst: Toxic ‘forever chemicals’ were found at a level 10 times higher than people who did not work in contaminated zoneNew research shows alarming levels of Pfas in the blood of people living or working near a US air force base responsible for polluting drinking water with high levels of the dangerous “forever chemicals”, a new state regulatory report has found.The levels are high enough in those who lived and worked near the Cannon air force base in Curry county to raise health concerns – about 10 times above the levels of those in the region who did not work in the contaminated zone. The pollution stems from a type of Pfas-laden firefighting foam the military has used across the nation, and the types of compounds found at high levels in participants’ blood were also commonly used in foam. Continue reading...
items.content: Toxic ‘forever chemicals’ were found at a level 10 times higher than people who did not work in contaminated zoneNew research shows alarming levels of Pfas in the blood of people living or working near a US air force base responsible for polluting drinking water with high levels of the dangerous “forever chemicals”, a new state regulatory report has found.The levels are high enough in those who lived and worked near the Cannon air force base in Curry county to raise health concerns – about 10 times above the levels of those in the region who did not work in the contaminated zone. The pollution stems from a type of Pfas-laden firefighting foam the military has used across the nation, and the types of compounds found at high levels in participants’ blood were also commonly used in foam. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study found alarming levels of PFAS in blood near a US air force base.
Levels were ten times higher than those not in the contaminated zone.
The pollution stems from firefighting foam.
The study was conducted near Cannon Air Force Base.
The article highlights health concerns related to PFAS exposure.

clusters.title: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs
clusters.neutral_headline: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs: ‘Gourmand’ fragrances with notes of biscuit or cherries are also trending among young consumers online

items.title: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs
items.standfirst: ‘Gourmand’ fragrances with notes of biscuit or cherries are also trending among young consumers onlineA rise in the number of sweet, food-scented perfumes on the market could be linked to an increase in the use of weight-loss medication, according to the market research firm Mintel.Food-inspired fragrances, with scent profiles that feature vanilla, coffee and caramel and referred to in the industry as “gourmand” perfumes, have surged in popularity in the past three years. Launches of sugary-scented, dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24% last year alone, Mintel said. Continue reading...
items.content: ‘Gourmand’ fragrances with notes of biscuit or cherries are also trending among young consumers onlineA rise in the number of sweet, food-scented perfumes on the market could be linked to an increase in the use of weight-loss medication, according to the market research firm Mintel.Food-inspired fragrances, with scent profiles that feature vanilla, coffee and caramel and referred to in the industry as “gourmand” perfumes, have surged in popularity in the past three years. Launches of sugary-scented, dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24% last year alone, Mintel said. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the rise of food-scented perfumes.
It suggests a link to the use of weight-loss medications.
"Gourmand" perfumes are trending among young consumers.
Launches of sugary-scented fragrances increased by 24% last year.
The market research firm Mintel provided the data.
